msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This manuscript is a twelfth-century copy of John Cassian's Collationes, twenty-four conversations with prominent monks about monastic life, recommended for monastic reading in the Benedictine rule. The text is now incomplete, lacking Collations 12, 16-22, and 24. It is in two parts, described in thirteenth-century notes inside the front cover as Decem collationes Cassiani ad beatum papam Leontium (Collationes I-X, fols. 1-103) and Collationes Abbatis Nesterotis de spirituali scientia (Collationes 13-15, 23, 11, fols. 104-143). Both parts are written in protogothic script and may have been written in England, but they are different in ruling, hand, and ornamentation, with the text of the second part somewhat later in date and the initials possibly even later.

msItem.title: Decem collationes Cassiani ad beatum Papam Leontium
msItem.explicit: ... ad d[eum] versiculi hui[us] meditatione seruauerint. [fol. 103r]

msItem.title: Collationes Abbatis Nesterotis de spirituali sciencia

supportDesc.extent: i+143; 244 x 160 mm bound to 250 x 170 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

p.catchwords: Horizontal catchwords in ink, lower center last verso, Quires 13-16

layoutDesc.layout: One column of thirty-two to thirty-seven lines; frame-ruled in hard point with double horizontal bounding lines (fols. 1-103) and double vertical and horizontal bounding lines (fols. 104-143); prickings visible; text starts above top line throughout; written area: 185 x 100 mm (fols. 1-103), 182 x 100 (fols. 104-143)

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written by at least three hands: scribe 1 is responsible for fols. 1r-10v, 13r-102v; scribe 2 for fols. 11r-12v; scribe 3 for fols. 104r-143r (more rounded, possibly English and slightly later)

decoDesc.decoNote: One nine-line initial in green and red (fol. 1r) and numerous one- to four-line initials in red in the first part of the manuscript (fols. 1r-102v); four four- to ten-line initials in green and red (fols. 104r, 114r, 119r, 135v) and numerous three- or four-line initials in red, green, red and green, or blue in the second part of the manuscript (fols. 104r-143r); rubrication in red throughout

binding.p: Contemporary monastic binding of white leather (torn in places) over boards with one leather clasp; evidence of worn tooling patterns or ink-dyed finishing partially visible on back cover; partially legible inscription written vertically on lower half of upper cover: Lib… de Vr…..

history.provenance: Cope family at Bramshill Park, Hampshire; Sir Anthony Cope sale, Sotheby's, London, March 4 1913, lot 42; sold to Leighton (dealer); John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; gift of Anne Baker Lewis to the Free Library of Philadelphia, 1936
